title: SeuratVisPro Tutorial
text: SourceCode: https://github.com/benben-miao/SeuratVisPro/ Website API: https://benben-miao.github.io/SeuratVisPro/ SeuratVisPro innovative visualization diagnostic toolkit Seurat v5. provides cluster stability assessment, batch mixing diagnostics, marker atlas visualization, ligand–receptor directional scoring, gene trend plotting, dendrograms similarity heatmaps, spatial overlays non-spatial fallbacks, module score visualization, cell cycle views, . optional bs4Dash Shiny app bundled interactive exploration.

title: SeuratVisPro Tutorial
code: # From GitHub # install.packages("remotes") # remotes::install_github("benben-miao/SeuratVisPro")  library(SeuratVisPro) #> SeuratVisPro 0.1.0 - Innovative Seurat v5 visualization toolkit library(Seurat) #> Loading required package: SeuratObject #> Loading required package: sp #>  #> Attaching package: 'SeuratObject' #> The following objects are masked from 'package:base': #>  #>     intersect, t library(ggplot2)

title: SeuratVisPro Tutorial
code: launchSeuratVisPro()

title: SeuratVisPro Tutorial
code: obj <- SeuratVisProExample(   n_cells = 300,   n_genes = 1000,   n_clusters = 10,   seed = 123,   genes_mt = "^MT-",   neighbor_dims = 10,   cluster_res = 0.5,   umap_dims = 10,   spatial = FALSE ) #> Modularity Optimizer version 1.3.0 by Ludo Waltman and Nees Jan van Eck #>  #> Number of nodes: 300 #> Number of edges: 4508 #>  #> Running Louvain algorithm... #> Maximum modularity in 10 random starts: 0.9485 #> Number of communities: 10 #> Elapsed time: 0 seconds #> Warning: The default method for RunUMAP has changed from calling Python UMAP via reticulate to the R-native UWOT using the cosine metric #> To use Python UMAP via reticulate, set umap.method to 'umap-learn' and metric to 'correlation' #> This message will be shown once per session  Seurat::DimPlot(obj, group.by = "cluster")

title: SeuratVisPro Tutorial
code: p <- VisQCPanel(   obj,   assay = NULL,   genes_mt = "^MT-",   genes_ribo = "^RPL|^RPS",   group.by = "seurat_clusters",   interactive = FALSE,   palette = "C",   violin_width = 0.8,   violin_alpha = 0.3,   box_width = 0.3,   box_alpha = 0.5 )  p

title: SeuratVisPro Tutorial
code: res <- VisMarkerAtlas(   obj,   markers_top = 5,   logfc_threshold = 0.25,   min_percent = 0.1,   test_method = "wilcox",   palette = "C" ) #> Calculating cluster 0 #> For a (much!) faster implementation of the Wilcoxon Rank Sum Test, #> (default method for FindMarkers) please install the presto package #> -------------------------------------------- #> install.packages('devtools') #> devtools::install_github('immunogenomics/presto') #> -------------------------------------------- #> After installation of presto, Seurat will automatically use the more  #> efficient implementation (no further action necessary). #> This message will be shown once per session #> Calculating cluster 1 #> Calculating cluster 2 #> Calculating cluster 3 #> Calculating cluster 4 #> Calculating cluster 5 #> Calculating cluster 6 #> Calculating cluster 7 #> Calculating cluster 8 #> Calculating cluster 9 #> As of Seurat v5, we recommend using AggregateExpression to perform pseudo-bulk analysis. #> First group.by variable `ident` starts with a number, appending `g` to ensure valid variable names #> This message is displayed once per session.  res$plot head(res$markers) #> # A tibble: 6 × 7 #>      p_val avg_log2FC pct.1 pct.2 p_val_adj cluster gene  #>      <dbl>      <dbl> <dbl> <dbl>     <dbl> <fct>   <chr> #> 1 9.50e-19       1.80 1     0.622  9.50e-16 0       G848  #> 2 1.86e-17       1.83 0.976 0.622  1.86e-14 0       G809  #> 3 1.92e-17       1.62 1     0.653  1.92e-14 0       G844  #> 4 3.46e-17       1.69 1     0.653  3.46e-14 0       G859  #> 5 3.79e-17       1.73 0.976 0.653  3.79e-14 0       G847  #> 6 5.19e-19       1.97 1     0.563  5.19e-16 1       G901

title: SeuratVisPro Tutorial
code: obj$batch <- sample(c('A','B'), ncol(obj), replace = TRUE)  res <- VisBatchAlign(   obj,   batch = 'batch',   reduction = 'pca',   dims = 1:10,   k = 20,   palette = "C",   violin_width = 0.8,   violin_alpha = 0.3,   box_width = 0.3,   box_alpha = 0.5 )  res$plot head(res$summary) #> # A tibble: 6 × 3 #>   cell  mix_prop batch #>   <chr>    <dbl> <chr> #> 1 Cell1     0.5  A     #> 2 Cell2     0.6  B     #> 3 Cell3     0.45 A     #> 4 Cell4     0.6  A     #> 5 Cell5     0.5  B     #> 6 Cell6     0.55 A

title: SeuratVisPro Tutorial
code: p <- VisGeneTrend(   obj,   features = c("G10", "G20", "G30"),   by = "pseudotime",   reduction = "umap",   dims = 1:2,   smooth.method = "loess",   palette = "C",   point_size = 2,   point_alpha = 0.3,   smooth_alpha = 0.3,   smooth_linewidth = 1.5 )  p #> `geom_smooth()` using formula = 'y ~ x'

title: SeuratVisPro Tutorial
code: lr <- data.frame(ligand = paste0('G', 1:5), receptor = paste0('G', 6:10))  res <- VisLigRec(   obj,   assay = NULL,   lr_table = lr,   group.by = "seurat_clusters",   palette = "C",   tile_alpha = 0.8 )  res$plot head(res$scores) #> # A tibble: 6 × 3 #>   source target score #>   <chr>  <chr>  <dbl> #> 1 g0     g0      74.8 #> 2 g0     g1      80.5 #> 3 g0     g2      74.3 #> 4 g0     g3      74.0 #> 5 g0     g4      72.1 #> 6 g0     g5      71.4

title: SeuratVisPro Tutorial
code: p <- VisClusterTree(   obj,   assay = NULL,   group.by = "seurat_clusters",   dist.metric = "euclidean",   linkage = "complete",   show_heatmap = TRUE,   palette = "C",   tile_alpha = 0.8 )  p

title: SeuratVisPro Tutorial
code: sets <- list(SetA = paste0('G', 1:10), SetB = paste0('G', 11:20))  res <- VisMetaFeature(   obj,   feature_sets = sets,   group.by = "seurat_clusters",   nbin = 24,   min.size = 3,   palette = "C",   violin_width = 0.8,   violin_alpha = 0.3,   box_width = 0.3,   box_alpha = 0.5 )  res$plot

title: SeuratVisPro Tutorial
code: genes_s <- paste0('G', 1:10) genes_g2m <- paste0('G', 11:20)  res <- VisCellCycle(   obj,   genes_s,   genes_g2m,   reduction = "umap",   dims = 1:10,   palette = "C",   alpha = 0.8 )  res$plot

title: SeuratVisPro Tutorial
code: p <- VisEmbeddingContour(   obj,   group.by = "seurat_clusters",   reduction = "umap",   levels = 5,   palette = "C",   point_size = 1,   point_alpha = 0.5,   contour_alpha = 0.1 )  p

title: SeuratVisPro Tutorial
code: p <- VisGeneCoexpHive(   obj,   genes = paste0("G", 1:100),   reduction = "pca",   threshold = 0.2,   palette = "C",   point_size = 3,   point_alpha = 0.8,   label_size = 3,   curve_alpha = 0.5 ) #> Warning: The `slot` argument of `GetAssayData()` is deprecated as of SeuratObject 5.0.0. #> ℹ Please use the `layer` argument instead. #> ℹ The deprecated feature was likely used in the SeuratVisPro package. #>   Please report the issue at #>   <https://github.com/benben-miao/SeuratVisPro/issues>. #> This warning is displayed once every 8 hours. #> Call `lifecycle::last_lifecycle_warnings()` to see where this warning was #> generated. #> Warning: Using `size` aesthetic for lines was deprecated in ggplot2 3.4.0. #> ℹ Please use `linewidth` instead. #> ℹ The deprecated feature was likely used in the SeuratVisPro package. #>   Please report the issue at #>   <https://github.com/benben-miao/SeuratVisPro/issues>. #> This warning is displayed once every 8 hours. #> Call `lifecycle::last_lifecycle_warnings()` to see where this warning was #> generated.  p

title: SeuratVisPro Tutorial
code: obj_sp <- SeuratVisProExample(n_cells = 300, n_genes = 1000, n_clusters = 10, spatial = TRUE) #> Modularity Optimizer version 1.3.0 by Ludo Waltman and Nees Jan van Eck #>  #> Number of nodes: 300 #> Number of edges: 4508 #>  #> Running Louvain algorithm... #> Maximum modularity in 10 random starts: 0.9485 #> Number of communities: 10 #> Elapsed time: 0 seconds  p <- VisSpatialOverlay(   obj_sp,   features = c("G1", "G2", "G3", "G4"),   image = NULL,   coords_cols = c("x", "y"),   palette = "C",   point_size = 2,   alpha = 0.5 )  p

title: SeuratVisPro Tutorial
code: p <- VisHexEntropy(   obj,   group.by = "seurat_clusters",   reduction = "umap",   bins = 30,   palette = "C" )  p

title: SeuratVisPro Tutorial
code: p <- VisLocalMoran(   obj,   gene = 'G10',   reduction = "umap",   k = 15,   palette = "C",   point_size = 2,   point_alpha = 0.8 )  p

title: SeuratVisPro Tutorial
code: p <- VisClusterFlowGraph(   obj,   group.by = "seurat_clusters",   reduction = "umap",   palette = "C",   point_size = 7,   point_alpha = 0.9,   label_size = 5 )  p

title: Innovative Visualization and Analysis Toolkit for Seurat v5
text: SourceCode: https://github.com/benben-miao/SeuratVisPro/ Website API: https://benben-miao.github.io/SeuratVisPro/ SeuratVisPro innovative visualization diagnostic toolkit Seurat v5. provides cluster stability assessment, batch mixing diagnostics, marker atlas visualization, ligand–receptor directional scoring, gene trend plotting, dendrograms similarity heatmaps, spatial overlays non-spatial fallbacks, module score visualization, cell cycle views, . optional bs4Dash Shiny app bundled interactive exploration.

title: Innovative Visualization and Analysis Toolkit for Seurat v5
code: # From GitHub # install.packages("remotes") # remotes::install_github("benben-miao/SeuratVisPro")  library(SeuratVisPro) #> SeuratVisPro 0.1.0 - Innovative Seurat v5 visualization toolkit library(Seurat) #> Loading required package: SeuratObject #> Loading required package: sp #>  #> Attaching package: 'SeuratObject' #> The following objects are masked from 'package:base': #>  #>     intersect, t library(ggplot2)

title: Innovative Visualization and Analysis Toolkit for Seurat v5
code: res <- VisMarkerAtlas(   obj,   markers_top = 5,   logfc_threshold = 0.25,   min_percent = 0.1,   test_method = "wilcox",   palette = "C" ) #> Calculating cluster 0 #> For a (much!) faster implementation of the Wilcoxon Rank Sum Test, #> (default method for FindMarkers) please install the presto package #> -------------------------------------------- #> install.packages('devtools') #> devtools::install_github('immunogenomics/presto') #> -------------------------------------------- #> After installation of presto, Seurat will automatically use the more  #> efficient implementation (no further action necessary). #> This message will be shown once per session #> Calculating cluster 1 #> Calculating cluster 2 #> Calculating cluster 3 #> Calculating cluster 4 #> Calculating cluster 5 #> Calculating cluster 6 #> Calculating cluster 7 #> Calculating cluster 8 #> Calculating cluster 9 #> As of Seurat v5, we recommend using AggregateExpression to perform pseudo-bulk analysis. #> First group.by variable `ident` starts with a number, appending `g` to ensure valid variable names #> This message is displayed once per session.  res$plot head(res$markers) #> # A tibble: 6 × 7 #>      p_val avg_log2FC pct.1 pct.2 p_val_adj cluster gene  #>      <dbl>      <dbl> <dbl> <dbl>     <dbl> <fct>   <chr> #> 1 9.50e-19       1.80 1     0.622  9.50e-16 0       G848  #> 2 1.86e-17       1.83 0.976 0.622  1.86e-14 0       G809  #> 3 1.92e-17       1.62 1     0.653  1.92e-14 0       G844  #> 4 3.46e-17       1.69 1     0.653  3.46e-14 0       G859  #> 5 3.79e-17       1.73 0.976 0.653  3.79e-14 0       G847  #> 6 5.19e-19       1.97 1     0.563  5.19e-16 1       G901

title: Innovative Visualization and Analysis Toolkit for Seurat v5
code: obj$batch <- sample(c('A','B'), ncol(obj), replace = TRUE)  res <- VisBatchAlign(   obj,   batch = 'batch',   reduction = 'pca',   dims = 1:10,   k = 20,   palette = "C",   violin_width = 0.8,   violin_alpha = 0.3,   box_width = 0.3,   box_alpha = 0.5 )  res$plot head(res$summary) #> # A tibble: 6 × 3 #>   cell  mix_prop batch #>   <chr>    <dbl> <chr> #> 1 Cell1     0.5  A     #> 2 Cell2     0.6  B     #> 3 Cell3     0.45 A     #> 4 Cell4     0.6  A     #> 5 Cell5     0.5  B     #> 6 Cell6     0.55 A

title: Innovative Visualization and Analysis Toolkit for Seurat v5
code: p <- VisGeneTrend(   obj,   features = c("G10", "G20", "G30"),   by = "pseudotime",   reduction = "umap",   dims = 1:2,   smooth.method = "loess",   palette = "C",   point_size = 2,   point_alpha = 0.3,   smooth_alpha = 0.3,   smooth_linewidth = 1.5 )  p #> `geom_smooth()` using formula = 'y ~ x'

title: Innovative Visualization and Analysis Toolkit for Seurat v5
code: lr <- data.frame(ligand = paste0('G', 1:5), receptor = paste0('G', 6:10))  res <- VisLigRec(   obj,   assay = NULL,   lr_table = lr,   group.by = "seurat_clusters",   palette = "C",   tile_alpha = 0.8 )  res$plot head(res$scores) #> # A tibble: 6 × 3 #>   source target score #>   <chr>  <chr>  <dbl> #> 1 g0     g0      74.8 #> 2 g0     g1      80.5 #> 3 g0     g2      74.3 #> 4 g0     g3      74.0 #> 5 g0     g4      72.1 #> 6 g0     g5      71.4

title: Innovative Visualization and Analysis Toolkit for Seurat v5
code: p <- VisClusterTree(   obj,   assay = NULL,   group.by = "seurat_clusters",   dist.metric = "euclidean",   linkage = "complete",   show_heatmap = TRUE,   palette = "C",   tile_alpha = 0.8 )  p

title: Innovative Visualization and Analysis Toolkit for Seurat v5
code: sets <- list(SetA = paste0('G', 1:10), SetB = paste0('G', 11:20))  res <- VisMetaFeature(   obj,   feature_sets = sets,   group.by = "seurat_clusters",   nbin = 24,   min.size = 3,   palette = "C",   violin_width = 0.8,   violin_alpha = 0.3,   box_width = 0.3,   box_alpha = 0.5 )  res$plot

title: Innovative Visualization and Analysis Toolkit for Seurat v5
code: genes_s <- paste0('G', 1:10) genes_g2m <- paste0('G', 11:20)  res <- VisCellCycle(   obj,   genes_s,   genes_g2m,   reduction = "umap",   dims = 1:10,   palette = "C",   alpha = 0.8 )  res$plot

title: Innovative Visualization and Analysis Toolkit for Seurat v5
code: p <- VisEmbeddingContour(   obj,   group.by = "seurat_clusters",   reduction = "umap",   levels = 5,   palette = "C",   point_size = 1,   point_alpha = 0.5,   contour_alpha = 0.1 )  p

what: Generate Seurat object for demonstrations — SeuratVisProExample
title: Generate Seurat object for demonstrations — SeuratVisProExample
text: Generate Seurat object basic preprocessing (DefaultAssay, PercentageFeatureSet, NormalizeData, FindVariableFeatures, ScaleData, RunPCA, FindNeighbors, FindClusters, RunUMAP).

title: Generate Seurat object for demonstrations — SeuratVisProExample
code: SeuratVisProExample(   n_cells = 300,   n_genes = 1000,   n_clusters = 10,   seed = 123,   genes_mt = "^MT-",   neighbor_dims = 10,   cluster_res = 0.5,   umap_dims = 10,   spatial = FALSE )

title: Generate Seurat object for demonstrations — SeuratVisProExample
text: n_cells Number cells. Default: 300. n_genes Number genes. Default: 1000. n_clusters Number clusters. Default: 10. seed Random seed reproducibility. Default: 123. genes_mt Regex mitochondrial genes. Default: "^MT-". neighbor_dims Neighbor graph dimensions used FindNeighbors. Default: 10. cluster_res Cluster resolution used FindClusters. Default: 0.5. umap_dims UMAP dimensions used RunUMAP. Default: 10. spatial Whether add synthetic spatial coordinates x,y meta.data. Default: FALSE.

title: Generate Seurat object for demonstrations — SeuratVisProExample
text: Seurat object basic preprocessing steps applied.

title: Generate Seurat object for demonstrations — SeuratVisProExample
text: benben-miao

title: Generate Seurat object for demonstrations — SeuratVisProExample
code: obj <- SeuratVisProExample(     n_cells = 300,     n_genes = 1000,     n_clusters = 10,     seed = 123,     genes_mt = "^MT-",     neighbor_dims = 10,     cluster_res = 0.5,     umap_dims = 10,     spatial = FALSE) #> Modularity Optimizer version 1.3.0 by Ludo Waltman and Nees Jan van Eck #>  #> Number of nodes: 300 #> Number of edges: 4508 #>  #> Running Louvain algorithm... #> Maximum modularity in 10 random starts: 0.9485 #> Number of communities: 10 #> Elapsed time: 0 seconds #> Warning: The default method for RunUMAP has changed from calling Python UMAP via reticulate to the R-native UWOT using the cosine metric #> To use Python UMAP via reticulate, set umap.method to 'umap-learn' and metric to 'correlation' #> This message will be shown once per session  Seurat::DimPlot(obj, group.by = "cluster")

text: Quantify visualize batch mixing KNN graph /integration.

title: Batch mixing diagnostics — VisBatchAlign
code: VisBatchAlign(   object,   batch,   reduction = "pca",   dims = 1:10,   k = 20,   palette = "C",   violin_width = 0.8,   violin_alpha = 0.3,   box_width = 0.3,   box_alpha = 0.5 )

title: Batch mixing diagnostics — VisBatchAlign
text: object Seurat object; required. batch Column object@meta.data indicating batch; required. reduction Reduction kNN computation, 'pca' 'umap'. Default: 'pca'. dims Integer vector dimensions used. Default: 1:10. k Number neighbors. Default: 20. palette Viridis palette option color/fill. Default: "C". violin_width Violin width. Default: 0.8. violin_alpha Violin alpha. Default: 0.3. box_width Box width. Default: 0.3. box_alpha Box alpha. Default: 0.5.

code: obj <- SeuratVisProExample(     n_cells = 300,     n_genes = 1000,     n_clusters = 10,     seed = 123,     genes_mt = "^MT-",     neighbor_dims = 10,     cluster_res = 0.5,     umap_dims = 10,     spatial = FALSE) #> Modularity Optimizer version 1.3.0 by Ludo Waltman and Nees Jan van Eck #>  #> Number of nodes: 300 #> Number of edges: 4508 #>  #> Running Louvain algorithm... #> Maximum modularity in 10 random starts: 0.9485 #> Number of communities: 10 #> Elapsed time: 0 seconds  genes_s <- paste0('G', 1:10); genes_g2m <- paste0('G', 11:20)  res <- VisCellCycle(   obj,   genes_s,   genes_g2m,   reduction = "umap",   dims = 1:10,   palette = "C",   alpha = 0.8)  res$plot  res$cluster  res$bar

code: obj <- SeuratVisProExample(     n_cells = 300,     n_genes = 1000,     n_clusters = 10,     seed = 123,     genes_mt = "^MT-",     neighbor_dims = 10,     cluster_res = 0.5,     umap_dims = 10,     spatial = FALSE) #> Modularity Optimizer version 1.3.0 by Ludo Waltman and Nees Jan van Eck #>  #> Number of nodes: 300 #> Number of edges: 4508 #>  #> Running Louvain algorithm... #> Maximum modularity in 10 random starts: 0.9485 #> Number of communities: 10 #> Elapsed time: 0 seconds  lr <- data.frame(   ligand = paste0('G', 1:5),   receptor = paste0('G', 6:10))  res <- VisLigRec(   obj,   assay = NULL,   lr_table = lr,   group.by = "seurat_clusters",   palette = "C",   tile_alpha = 0.8)  res$plot  head(res$scores) #> # A tibble: 6 × 3 #>   source target score #>   <chr>  <chr>  <dbl> #> 1 g0     g0      74.8 #> 2 g0     g1      80.5 #> 3 g0     g2      74.3 #> 4 g0     g3      74.0 #> 5 g0     g4      72.1 #> 6 g0     g5      71.4
